questions.question: Which of the areas in the histology of lymph nodes show small, unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining germinal centres?
questions.explanation: The mantle zone is the area in the histology of lymph nodes where small, unchallenged B cells surround pale-staining germinal centres.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a B lymphocyte marker?
questions.explanation: CD13 is an antigen of monocyte/macrophage and not B-cell.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding Non-Hodgkin lymphoma?

options.A: It involves multiple peripheral lymph nodes
options.B: Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are rarely involved

questions.explanation: Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).503

questions.question: Which is the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults?
questions.explanation: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma(NHL) in adults and children over the age of 15 years, worldwide and in India.Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common NHL in children under the age of 15 years.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a B-cell neoplasm?
questions.explanation: Anaplastic large cell lymphoma is a T-cell lymphoma.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site for primary extranodal lymphoma?
questions.explanation: The most common site for primary extranodal lymphoma is the stomach.The term primary extranodal non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (PE-NHL) refers to lymphomas thatpresent with the disease at any organ or tissue other than lymph nodes or spleen.Gastrointestinal lymphoma is the most common form of primary extranodal lymphoma,accounting for 30%-40% of cases. The most common site involved is the stomach (60%-75% ofcases), followed by the small bowel, ileum, cecum, colon, and rectum.Note: The most common site for extranodal non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in AIDS is PrimaryCNS lymphoma.

questions.question: Which lymphoid neoplasm is associated with the human herpesvirus 8?
questions.explanation: Primary effusion lymphoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).It is a rare type of diffuse large B cell lymphoma with lymphomatous effusions in pleural,pericardial, and abdominal cavities, but no tumor mass.Only one body cavity is typically involved. It is strongly associated with HHV8 and advanced HIVand usually EBV. It can also occurs in non-immunosuppressed patients, often the elderly.

questions.explanation: The correctly matched neoplasms with their associated etiological factor:•Extranodal marginal cell lymphoma - H.pylori infection (c).Intestinal T-cell lymphomas - Gluten-sensitive enteropathy (d)•• Anaplastic large cell lymphoma - Breast implants (b)504• Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma - Hepatitis C infection (e)• Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma - HIV infection (a)505
